social_posts.post_text:
I couldn’t resist sharing this festive photo of ✨Joy✨ with you guys on this first day of December! 😍 This worsted-weight pattern is one of the 30 designs featured in my new book, The Art of Knitting Hats, and it’s so much fun to knit up! 🤗 (Peep my stories if you wanna see fit pics. 🤩) Starting with a fun, corrugated rib brim with stripes that continue into the body of the hat, Joy is packed with elongated stars and little diamonds near the crown to let your spirit shine. You can knit this baby in traditional holiday colors to celebrate the magic of the season, or you can totally switch up your palette and find joy at any time of the year! There also are options to create a scrappy version—just play around with whatever yarn you have in your stash to create a one-of-a-kind beauty for yourself or as a gift! 😘❤️
•
➰ Pattern: Joy is available in 📕The Art of Knitting Hats📕 and also as an individual pattern on my website, Etsy and Ravelry (links in profile)
•
🧶 Yarn: Worsted by @malabrigoyarn
•
✨ Faux Fur Pom: Made by me—I don’t sell this cream-colored beauty highlighted with flecks of gold tinsel but my awesome friend, Erin @lizzy_knits, has them ready to ship in her shop @threebirdsyarnstudio 🤗

🧶✂️🎄 A little festive Pom Art for you guys! 🎁 I had so much fun creating this one—from the trunk and little pops of color designed to look like ornaments all the way up to the star on top. 🌟 I hope you have an awesome weekend! 😘❤️
•
🧶✂️ I have a couple pom-making/Pom Art tutorials—from basic to more advanced (Heart Pom Art ❤️)—available on my YouTube channel. My Pie Chart Pom Art tutorial is eavailable on my website. (Links in profile)

🧶✂️🎄 Thank you so much for all the love you guys have shown for my latest pom art creation! 🥰 Your excitement inspired me to make a Christmas Tree Pom Art tutorial so you can create your own festive and fluffy fun, and it’s now available on my website and Etsy (links in profile)! 🎉🎁 The tutorial includes a downloadable PDF with general info about the project and a link to a video with step-by-step instructions for how to make the pom (intended for use as a social media prop or stand-alone art piece—not to top off hats). 😘 With an intermediate skill level, the tutorial is designed for makers who are comfortable with using a pom maker and making yarn poms. I hope you guys have so much yarn-y fun with this one! Happy holidays! ❤️🎄❤️
•
Oh! And as always, make sure you’re subscribed to my newsletter to gain access to discounts and be the first to know about new things coming your way. Subscribers got an early heads up about this tutorial going live and they also received a 🤑50% off!!!! coupon code to use to purchase it! 🤑 (link to my website where you can subscribe in profile) 
•
🧶✂️ My Heart Pom Art tutorial is available on my YouTube channel. My Pie Chart Pom Art tutorial is available on my website and Etsy. (links in profile)

Just wanted to bring you guys some cozy, winter vibes today. 🥰 This bulky-weight pattern called ❄️Snowfall❄️ is one of 30 designs featured in my new book, The Art of Knitting Hats, and with an easy skill level it’s the perfect accessory to make, wear and gift 🎁 on repeat throughout the season. (Peep my stories if you wanna see fit pics. 🤗) You can choose to make this stranded colorwork hat in either a fitted or slouchy style—there are instructions for both so you pick! There’s definitely no wrong answer. 😘❤️ 
•
➰ Pattern: Snowfall available in 📕The Art of Knitting Hats📕 and also as an individual pattern on my website, Etsy and Ravelry (links in profile)
•
🧶 Yarn: Fitted version—Chunky Singles by @mountainlaurelfiberco and Slouchy version—Mecha by @malabrigoyarn

🎁✨🎄The color combo on this baby is like holiday cheer wrapped up in a cowl—the Cozy Cord Cowl to be exact! 🤓🤣🤩 Seriously though, It’s given me lots of joy to see so many of you downloading this pattern lately, and your interest and excitement inspired me to make another one of my own to celebrate the season! ❤️💚 This design uses I-cords of varying widths and lengths to create a unique statement piece that flows freely. It knits up quickly, and it’s an awesome stash buster—just mix and match any combo of super bulky and/or bulky yarn you have on hand! 🤗 You can experiment with five or more colors, make a multi-colored braid or a create a cowl with similar, subtle shades. Consider it your own little wearable piece of art—have fun and make it whatever you want it to be! 😘❤️
•
➰ Pattern: Cozy Cord Cowl available on my website, Etsy and Ravelry (links in profile)
•
🧶 Yarn: MRGO by @mitchellscfiberarts, Postscript Aran by @iamfullyspun, The Squish by @mountainlaurelfiberco and Worsted and Chunky by @malabrigoyarn

Just so grateful for all the experiences, creativity and fun with fiber friends that 2022 brought! From an awesome retreat with @channypeascorner to my book release with @pagestreetpublishing and an amazing time at Rhinebeck with my knitting bestie @lizzy_knits—oh and lots of pom art goodness 🧶✂️—what an incredible 365 days it’s been. 🥰 Also, it’s crazy to see a year’s worth of your work go by in 25 seconds 🤣🤯—so many good times with @misspurlchicago, too! ❤️ Thank you guys for all your love and support and all the best to you in 2023! 🥂🥳🎉

🎵🧶 It takes two to make a stitch go right! 🤓🤣🤩 I love the look of two-color fisherman’s rib so much that I use it in several of my designs, including the Beeline Beanie (shown here in progress). This super stretchy and ultra squishy fabric is created by alternating rounds that include “knit 1 below” (k1b) and “purl 1 below” (p1b) stitches. And switching colors every other round really makes it pop. 🤗✨ For slower, more in-depth instructions on how to knit these stitches, just head over to my YouTube channel (link in bio). 🥰 
•
➰Pattern: Beeline Beanie (written for bulky and super bulky yarn) available on my website, Ravelry and Etsy (links in bio)
•
🧶Yarn: Noventa in the Sea Slug colorway gifted to me by my friends at @malabrigoyarn 🥰 and Chunky in Black, also by Malabrigo 
•
🧡Goodies: @ggmadeit valet tray and Georgia stitch markers from @birdieparkerdesigns

Here’s a finished shot of the Beeline Beanie I shared with you in progress in my last reel. 🤩 You guys have been giving this pattern—one of my first—lots of love lately, and that means so much to me! 🥰 Truly, thank you for each and every download! 😘❤️ This fisherman’s rib design is written for both bulky and super bulky yarn. 🤗 Alternating rounds that include “knit 1 below” (k1b) and “purl 1 below” (p1b) stitches are used to create a super stretchy and ultra squishy fabric. And using two different colors of yarn creates such an eye-catching effect! What color combo will you choose? 😎
•
➰Pattern: Beeline Beanie available on my website, Ravelry and Etsy (links in bio)
•
🧶Yarn: Noventa in the Sea Slug colorway gifted to me by my friends at @malabrigoyarn 🥰 and Chunky in Black, also by Malabrigo 
•
💥Pom: Made by me from scraps—more details to come on how to create a yarn pom that looks like your favorite variegated yarn 🤗

🧶✂️ Heres a little look at the making of that yarn pom on the Beeline Beanie I shared with you guys in my last post. 🤩 I used a bunch of odds and ends from my stash to create this beauty to match the hat. Using scraps in various weights and colors for poms is a great way to mimic the characteristics of variegated yarn without having to actually use any extra of it. 🙌 Have you tried making scrappy yarn poms? 🤗
•
💥: Don’t forget to check out my pom-making/Pom Art tutorials—from basic to more advanced (Heart Pom Art ❤️)—available on my YouTube channel. My Christmas Tree Pom Art Tutorial and my Pie Chart Pom Art Tutorial are available on my website. (Links in profile)

🎵🧶 A little Flip Fantasia for you guys! ✨ These hat flipping reels are seriously so fun to make that I thought I’d try one out using my ⏪️ To The Left ⏪️ pattern in alllll the colors! 🤩 This design features a bold, horizontal chevron pattern, and I wrote it for super bulky yarn so it knits up quickly. 🤗 There are endless color combos for this baby—six are shown in this reel. 🌈 Oh, and if you want to see a pic of all these hats together at once, 😉 just scroll down a bit in my feed or check my stories. I hope you guys have an awesome weekend! 😘❤️

🧶✂️ You guys know I love a good, scrappy pom! 🤩 I recently shared a reel about how to create a pom that matches your precious, variegated yarn…without using any of your precious, variegated yarn. 🙌 Well the same idea holds true for your precious, hand-dyed yarn in solid colors! Don’t feel like you have to use more of that hand-dyed yarn to make a pom. Just head to your stash and pull out some leftover odds and ends from different yarn in the same color families—they don’t have to be an exact match. 😉 This is a great way to use up those scraps and mimic the look of a pom made entirely with hand-dyed yarn! 🤗🧶❤️

🧶➰ Just over here having waaaaay too much fun weaving in ends! 🤣🎵💃🏻 How’s your weekend going so far?
•
Yarn: Thick & Quick by @lionbrandyarn

🧶➰ This is how I weave in ends when knitting with multiple colors. Who else does it the same way? 🙋🏻‍♀️ I use this method no matter what yarn weight I’m working with—even when using single-ply yarn. I find that by weaving the tail only through the top plies of the yarn (or directly through the middle of the fiber when working with single-ply yarn), unwanted color won’t poke through and be visible on the right side of your work. 🤗 I also find that weaving in vertically for hats helps to prevent tails from coming loose when stretched horizontally. What’s your favorite method for weaving in ends? There’s no right or wrong answers here—we all do what works best for us! 🤗🥰❤️
•
Yarn: Thick & Quick by @lionbrandyarn ❤️🧡💛💚

I’m sooooo super excited to introduce you guys to my very first sweater design: New Horizons! 🤗 🎉 I created this pattern to serve as an entry into sweater-making for anyone who loves to knit, adores stranded colorwork and has just been too intimidated to try a sweater. This worsted-weight design features simple colorwork and a minimalist approach to its seamless, top-down construction to keep things as easy as possible—I always resort to easy, my friends. 😘 It also was super important to me for this pattern to be size-inclusive so I wrote it for 10 different sizes that range from a full chest circumference of 33–66” (75–165) cm. 🙌 I’ll be breaking down a bunch of the elements of the sweater for you in upcoming posts, and I’ll be looking for testers soon 🤗 so keep an eye out for that. 👀 Sooooo many more details to come! In the meantime, peep my stories for fit pics. 😘❤️ 
•
➰ Pattern: New Horizons coming late summer/early autumn to my website, Etsy and Ravelry
•

✨UPDATE: TESTERS FOUND—thank you!!!✨ I am looking for testers for my New Horizons sweater pattern! 🤗➰ Please see the link to the test knit application in my profile. Testers will be notified by Tuesday, June 20. The test will begin that day and the deadline is Sunday, Aug. 20 (8+ week testing timeframe) for a late summer/early autumn pattern release!
•
New Horizons uses worsted weight yarn and is knit seamlessly from the top down. This circular yoke design features just a bit of colorwork to keep things simple. 🙌 I created this pattern to serve as an entry into sweater-making for anyone who loves to knit, is experienced in knitting stranded colorwork and has just been too intimidated to try a sweater. 🥰
•
The pattern is written for 10 different sizes that range from a full chest circumference of 33–66” (75–165) cm and the sweater is designed to be worn with -0.5”—+3.5” (-1.5 cm —+9 cm) positive ease. The finished garment measurements range from a full chest circumference of 31.5”—67.5” (79–169) cm. I am looking for one or two testers for each size. Suggested needles are US 4 (3.5 mm) and US 5 (3.75 mm), or size needed to meet gauge. 😊
•

🧶✂️ Do your yarn poms look as scraggly as mine straight off the pom maker? 🤣🙋🏻‍♀️ I’m guessing most do, so I wanted to share a few tips with you guys on shaping. 🤗 I get a lot of q’s about what tools I use and how I get my poms so round. My very first sweater pattern—New Horizons—is now live on my website, Etsy and Ravelry! 🤗 🎉 (Links in profile.) I created this pattern to serve as an entry into sweater-making for anyone who loves to knit, is experienced with colorwork and has just been too intimidated to try a sweater. This worsted-weight design features simple, stranded colorwork and a minimalist approach to its seamless, top-down construction to keep things as easy as possible—I always resort to easy, my friends. 😘 It also was super important to me for this pattern to be size-inclusive so I wrote it for 10 different sizes that range from a full chest circumference of 33–66” (75–165) cm. 🙌 I can’t wait to see all the color combos you guys come up with! 🤗

Have you ever knit something and not been in love with your initial color choice? 🙋🏻‍♀️ If you want to fix it and didn’t put in a lifeline earlier 😬, this is the method I use when I’ve knit more than a round or two and don’t want to rip back stitch by stitch. You can definitely just pick up the stitches directly with your circulars. But for something like a sweater with hundreds of stitches bunched on your needles, I find it waaaaay easier to use a long stitch holder cord. What’s your favorite way to rip back—if that’s even a legit question! 😆
